Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Blind Perfect Signal Reconstruction in Subsampled Multi-Channel Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Multi-channel systems arise whenever a signal is picked up in or sent to more than one location. They are ubiquitous in imaging and sensing, data communication and storage, and in all audio, speech, or image processing digital technologies. Their applications range from ultrasound or MRI diagnostic scanners, to radio astronomy. The rich theory of multi-channel systems addresses two scenarios: when the entire system, including the channels, can be freely designed; or when the channels may be fixed and unknown, but data at the output of each channel is fully acquired. However, in many important applications this is not the case. The characteristics of the channels are often dictated by the physics governing the sensing process, which are unknown because of interaction of the sensors with the environment or their miss-calibration. Furthermore, because of physical or cost constraints only partial (subsampled) channel data is available. The goal of this project is to develop, evaluate and demonstrate the fundamental theory and design tools to address this important class of problems.

This project aims to extend the methods of blind multi-channel deconvolution, which are currently limited to non-subsampled systems , to provide blind perfect signal reconstruction from subsampled data. The specific aims of this project are to: (1) develop the theory of blind identification of subsampled multi-channel systems; (2) propose practical methods for blind identification of such systems using perfect (or near perfect) reconstruction filter banks; (3) provide analytical tools to study and quantify various tradeoffs between conditioning (noise performance), signal distortion, robustness, and computational cost; and (4) to demonstrate performance gains on real applications, and in particular in highly-accelerated multi-channel magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and robust image super-resolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multi-channel data acquisition arises in various sensing and data processing modalities including data communication/storage, remote sensing, and medical imaging systems such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The channel outputs are sampled prior to digital processing. The objective is to perfectly reconstruct (recover) the input signal from the sampled channel signals i.e., to design the signal reconstruction mechanism. In many important applications the characteristics of the channels (e.g., sensors) are dictated by the physics governing the particular sensing or imaging device and therefore not only can they not be chosen at will, but they are also unknown in advance. Thus, recovery of the acquired signal must be done blindly, without knowledge of the channels through which the signal propagated. This “blind signal reconstruction” or “blind recovery” scenario is much more challenging than the non-blind case, and much less is known about it.

An initial focus in the project was on subsampled multi-channel systems with known channel responses. This work resulted in the following specific contributions: (i) a theory for determining the minimum required complexity, expressed as filter lengths, for a multi-channel reconstruction system; (ii) design of highly computationally efficient reconstruction systems that are nearly optimum in controlling noise in the reconstructed signal; and (iii) design of highly efficient and noise-optimal multichannel interpolation systems that recover the signal samples lost in subsampling, and thus “undo” the subsampling.

Building on the above results, resulted in the development of a new formulation and theory for blind signal recovery from multichannel subsampled data using a filter bank interpolation system. The developed method dubbed ACSIOM was applied to parallel (multi-channel) MRI (pMRI) where high subsampling factor is desired to achieve high acceleration.  ACSIOM was shown to be capable of reconstructing artifact-free images at high acceleration with minimal amount of calibration data, improving on the state-of-the-art method of GRAPPA. The theory of the new ACSIOM method also allows, for the first time, rigorous performance analysis, which is significant for understanding the limitations of self-calibrating pMRI in clinical applications; and enables to optimize the reconstruction parameters without the need for acquisition of additional data. The method has commercial potential, and a US patent has been issued for it.

Taking a broader view of  blind deconvolution, this is an instance of a bilinear inverse problem (BIP). While linear inverse problems are very well understood, little theory was known for BIPs, which are inherently more challenging, especially with subspace or sparsity constraints. In particular, although some methods reported empirical success, the fundamental conditions for unique and stable solution were not known. The research on this more general problem resulted in a unified framework for analyzing fundamental limits on identiability in BIPs. Within this framework, results were obtained for the problem of blind gain and phase calibration, which arises in in many applications, including inverse rendering in computer vision, and blind phase and gain calibration in sensor array processing and in multichannel blind deconvolution. The results are fundamental bounds in the form of algebraic conditions on the amount of data needed (so-called sample complexity) for unique recovery (identifiability). The bounds are optimal, matching the number of degrees of freedom in the unknowns. As such, they are the first of their kind for any bilinear inverse problem.
